question: Will Apple Maps display Gulf of America instead of Gulf of Mexico before April 1, 2025?
description: Newsweek: [Gulf of America? Not if You Use Apple, Google](https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-gulf-america-2018291) | [Apple Maps still calls it the Gulf of Mexico, and politicians are upset](https://appleinsider.com/articles/25/01/21/apple-maps-still-calls-it-the-gulf-of-mexico-and-politicians-are-upset)
fine_print: In case both names are used, for example "Gulf of America formerly known as Gulf of Mexico," this question resolves as Yes.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Apple's Big Plans for 2025: Expert Predicts Groundbreaking Year**
Tech-expert Torben Vognsen from Input predicts that 2025 will be a groundbreaking year for Apple, with several new products on the horizon. According to Vognsen, Apple will focus on releasing an ultra-thin iPhone model, possibly called iPhone 17 Slim or Air, which will be the thinnest on the market. Additionally, Apple will expand its 'Smart Home' ecosystem with a range of new products, including a 'HomeHub' solution that will serve as the digital hub of the home. This will allow users to control all their Smart Home functions, including lighting, temperature, and security, using a highly upgraded version of Siri. Vognsen also mentions that Apple will release a doorbell that can be used for FaceTime calls and will allow users to unlock their front door using their FaceID. Furthermore, Apple's AI-functionality, which was delayed in Europe due to regulatory uncertainty, is expected to be released in April, although the exact features are still unknown.

Publish date: February 08, 2025 09:10 PM

**iOS 18.4 Update: Apple Expected To Launch 1st Beta Next Week, Roll Out Final Update in April 2025; Check Anticipated Apple Intelligence Features and Upgrades | 📲 LatestLY**
Apple is expected to release the first beta version of iOS 18.4 next week, with a final update scheduled for April 2025. The update is expected to include major Siri upgrades with Apple Intelligence support, such as on-screen awareness, personalized understanding, and app control abilities. Additionally, Apple Intelligence may focus on artificial intelligence (AI) to add 'Priority Notifications,' allowing iPhone users to receive automatic highlights on specific notifications. The update may also add new languages, including Japanese, Korean, German, French, Vietnamese, Spanish, Italian, and Chinese, as well as new emojis. Apple may target beta launch testing until April 2025 before rolling out the final update.

**Apple Working on Minor iOS 18.3.1 Update Before Major iOS 18.4 Release**
Apple is reportedly working on a minor update, iOS 18.3.1, for iPhone devices before the major release of iOS 18.4 in April. According to a report, the update will focus on fixing bugs and patching security vulnerabilities. MacRumors has highlighted that iOS 18.3.1 is in development, and it is expected to be released in the coming weeks. The update is expected to be a minor one, similar to iOS 18.2.1, and will likely include fixes for any reported issues in previous updates, as well as security patches. The update will likely build upon the changes made in iOS 18.3, where Apple retreated from its intelligent content summaries after receiving criticism from some media outlets. Meanwhile, Apple is working on iOS 18.4, which is expected to include an updated version of Siri, allowing it to access user data and read screen content to provide more accurate answers. The update may also include the ability to analyze emails, messages, photos, calendar events, files, and other data to form relevant answers. Other expected changes include additional emojis and support for additional languages.

**Apple's First Foldable iPhone: Expected Release Date and Key Features**
Apple is expected to release its first foldable iPhone in 2026, with a 12-inch internal screen and a dual-camera setup. The phone will be foldable like a book, with a thickness of 9.2 mm when folded and 4.6 mm when open. According to Tipster, Apple will sell between 8 to 10 million units of the foldable iPhone in 2026, and 20 million units in 2027. The phone is expected to have an aluminum mid-frame, a triple-cell battery with a capacity of around 5000mAh, and a rear camera setup with a wide-angle lens. The phone's design is currently in development, with a prototype that can be folded like a heart. Apple is also expected to release a foldable iPad and MacBook in 2027.

**Apple Intelligence to be Available in Portuguese by April 2025**
Apple announced that Apple Intelligence will be available in Portuguese by April 2025. Currently, the feature is only available in English in Australia, Canada, Ireland, New Zealand, South Africa, the UK, and the US. With the upcoming update, Apple Intelligence will be expanded to include Chinese, English (India and Singapore), French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Spanish, Vietnamese, and other languages. According to Tim Cook, 'Thanks to the power of the Apple chip, we're offering new possibilities with Apple Intelligence, which ensures better and more personalized apps and experiences. And we're excited to offer Apple Intelligence in even more languages by April.' Since its launch in October 2024, Apple Intelligence has been limited to a few English-speaking countries. Starting in April, the company plans to expand support for various other languages, including Portuguese, making the technology more accessible to a global audience. Compatible devices include the iPhone 15 Pro, iPhone 15 Pro Max, iPhone 16, and newer models, as well as several iPad and MacBook models.

Source:[hardware.com.br](https://www.hardware.com.br/mobile/apple-intelligence-portugues-abril-2025/)

**Google Maps and Apple Maps to Change 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'Gulf of America'**
Google Maps will change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to 'Gulf of America' in the future, following the official renaming by the US government. Apple Maps has already started displaying the new name, but only when specifically searched for. The change will be applied globally, but with some exceptions. In Google Maps, US users will only see the new name, while users outside the US will see both the old and new names. Mexican users will still see the old name. Apple Maps currently displays the old name, but shows the new name when searched for. It is assumed that Apple will follow Google's approach and update the name once the change is made in the US government's database. The renaming was made official by a decree signed by former US President Trump on January 20, 2025, which also renamed the Mount McKinley in Alaska to Denali. According to the US government, the renaming aims to 'restore names that praise America's greatness'.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 30, 2025 03:26 PM
Source:[curved.de](https://curved.de/news/golf-von-amerika-google-maps-und-apple-maps-ziehen-mit-770002)

**Apple and Google Update Maps to Reflect Name Changes**
Following Donald Trump's decision to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the 'Gulf of America' and Mount McKinley to 'Mount McKinley', Apple and Google have been updating their maps to reflect the changes. Apple Maps still shows the 400-year-old name 'Gulf of Mexico' when navigating to the area, but displays 'Gulf of America' as a search result. Google Maps, on the other hand, has decided to display different names for the Gulf of Mexico depending on the region, listing the US as a 'sensitive' area. In the German version of Apple Maps, the name 'Gulf of Mexico' remains unchanged, while Google Maps also displays 'Gulf of Mexico' when searching for 'Gulf of America'. However, Apple Maps does display the correct name 'Denali' for the mountain, while Google Maps still shows 'Mount McKinley'.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 30, 2025 10:00 AM
Source:[macwelt.de](https://www.macwelt.de/article/2592683/gulf-of-america-apple.html)

**Apple Maps may have a solution for new Gulf of Mexico name**
Apple Maps has made a change to address the renaming of the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America, but it's unclear if this is a permanent solution or a placeholder. When users search for 'Gulf of America', the text over the Gulf changes to reflect the search result, but the information sheet still shows data and photos about the Gulf of Mexico. This solution may be enough to satisfy some users, but it's unlikely to satisfy all politicians. Apple has remained silent about the issue, but this change may be enough to stave off unwanted attention.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 11:45 PM
Source:[techtelegraph.co.uk](https://techtelegraph.co.uk/apple-maps-may-have-a-solution-for-new-gulf-of-mexico-name/)

**Apple Maps shows users the Gulf of Mexico when searching for 'Gulf of America' | AppleInsider**
Apple Maps has partially addressed the renaming of the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America, but it's unclear if this is a permanent solution or a placeholder. When searching for 'Gulf of America,' Apple Maps shows the expected location, but the information sheet still displays data and photos about the Gulf of Mexico. This solution may satisfy some users, but it's unlikely to appease politicians who are pushing for a full update. Google has stated that it will update Google Maps when the Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) is updated, but it still shows the Gulf of Mexico. Apple has remained silent on the issue, but this partial solution may be enough to stave off unwanted attention.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 11:31 PM
Source:[AppleInsider](https://appleinsider.com/articles/25/01/29/apple-maps-shows-users-the-gulf-of-mexico-when-searching-for-gulf-of-america)

**Apple Maps shows users the Gulf of Mexico when searching for 'Gulf of America'**
Apple Maps has partially addressed the renaming of the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America, but it is unclear if this is a permanent solution or a placeholder. When searching for 'Gulf of America,' Apple Maps shows the expected location, but the information sheet still displays data and photos about the Gulf of Mexico. This solution may be enough to satisfy users who search for the term, but it may not be enough to appease some politicians. Google has stated that they will update Google Maps when the Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) is updated, but for now, they still show the Gulf of Mexico. Apple has not commented on whether this is a permanent solution or not.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2025 11:30 PM
Source:[AppleInsider Forums](https://forums.appleinsider.com/discussion/239083/apple-maps-shows-users-the-gulf-of-mexico-when-searching-for-gulf-of-america)

**Google Updates Maps to Reflect Trump's Renaming of US Landmarks, Meta Challenges Apple's ATT Policy, and Peanut Expands to Brazil**
US President Donald Trump's first action was to rename the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America and Denali to Mount McKinley through an executive order. In response, Google announced that it will update Google Maps to reflect the changes once the US official geographic name system (GNIS) confirms them, which should occur within 30 days. Although the decree does not obligate companies to adopt the new names, Google stated that it will follow its practice of using official government designations. For US users, the new names will appear as 'Gulf of America' and 'Mount McKinley.' Internationally, Google Maps will display both names, along with globally recognized names, such as 'Gulf of Mexico.' The change raises questions about the impact of national policies on global tools. The Google emphasized that it will maintain its standard approach of displaying both names in cases of discrepancies between countries. Additionally, Meta has filed a complaint with the CADE against Apple, questioning the App Tracking Transparency (ATT) policy introduced by Apple in 2021. Meta argues that Apple applies less restrictive rules to its own apps, while third-party apps face explicit pop-ups. The case is part of investigations in France, Germany, and the US, where the Department of Justice is examining ATT as a possible abuse of dominant position by Apple. The move follows Mercado Livre's complaint to the CADE, resulting in a preventive measure against Apple. Furthermore, the social networking app Peanut, created by Michelle Kennedy, is expanding its operations to Brazil, driven by user requests and research highlighting a strong taboo surrounding motherhood in the country. The app offers a safe and welcoming environment for discussing topics like mental health, childbirth, and menopause, and has over 3 million monthly users and $30 million in investments.
Original language: pt
Publish date: January 29, 2025 10:10 AM
Source:[TecMundo](https://www.tecmundo.com.br/mercado/401955-o-tinder-para-mamaes-esta-chegando-ao-brasil---the-brief-2901.htm)

**Google Maps to Display 'Gulf of America' in US, Following US Government Request**
Google Maps will display the 'Gulf of America' name for the Gulf of Mexico in the US, following a request from the US government. Google stated, 'We have a long-standing practice of applying changes when they have been applied in official government sources.' The change will only be visible to users in the US, while users in Mexico and other countries will see both 'Gulf of Mexico' and 'Gulf of America' with the latter in parentheses. This modification is part of Google's practice of updating names when they are changed in official government sources. The change is expected to be made when the US updates its official maps, and Google will follow suit. The New York Times reported that Google will make the changes 'quickly' to reflect the name change in the body of water shared by countries such as Mexico, the US, and Cuba. It is unclear if Apple's Maps app will make the same modification.
Original language: es
Publish date: January 28, 2025 03:11 PM
Source:[proyectopuente.com.mx](https://proyectopuente.com.mx/2025/01/28/google-maps-le-dara-el-gusto-a-trump-y-mostrara-golfo-de-america-en-su-app-en-eeuu/)

**When will Apple Maps and Google Maps use ‘Gulf of America,’ ‘Mount McKinley?’**
Following President Donald Trump's executive order to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the 'Gulf of America' and Denali to 'Mount McKinley,' Apple Maps and Google Maps have yet to update their platforms. However, Trump's order included a 30-day timeframe for modifications to be made, and it's possible that changes may occur in the near future. As of now, Apple Maps still labels the gulf as 'Gulf of Mexico,' but a search for 'Gulf of America' brings the user to the correct location. The Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) still lists the sea as the Gulf of Mexico and the summit as Denali.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 24, 2025 02:08 PM
Source:[macdailynews.com](https://macdailynews.com/2025/01/24/when-will-apple-maps-and-google-maps-use-gulf-of-america-mount-mckinley/)

**Google and Apple Maps still list Gulf of Mexico, not America, per Trump's order**
Despite President Trump's executive order to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America and Denali to Mount McKinley, Google and Apple Maps still list the Gulf of Mexico and Denali by their original names. The order, issued on January 24, 2025, directed the U.S. government's Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) to remove all references to the Gulf of Mexico, but corporations such as Google and Apple are not bound by the directive. As of the time of writing, searching for 'Gulf of America' on Apple Maps directs users to the Gulf of Alaska, while Google Maps shows a list of businesses called 'Gulf America.' Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum has already reacted to the order, stating, 'For us, it is still the Gulf of Mexico, and for the entire world, it is still the Gulf of Mexico.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: January 24, 2025 12:56 PM
Source:[Mashable](https://mashable.com/article/google-apple-maps-gulf-mexico-america-denali-mckinley)

**Dan Crenshaw Complains to Tim Cook That Apple Maps Hasn't Changed 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'Gulf of America'**
Dan Crenshaw complained to Apple CEO Tim Cook that Apple Maps still refers to the 'Gulf of Mexico', despite a recent executive order by Trump to rename it the 'Gulf of America'. Crenshaw, who attached a photo of him filing a complaint to Apple, noted that the change has not yet taken effect. Trump's executive order, which was signed on Monday, directs the Secretary of the Interior to rename the U.S. Continental Shelf area bounded by Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida to the Gulf of America within 30 days. Florida has already officially renamed the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America, using the new name on an emergency weather warning just hours after Trump's inauguration.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 23, 2025 12:10 PM
Source:[Mediaite](https://www.mediaite.com/politics/dan-crenshaw-complains-to-tim-cook-that-apple-maps-hasnt-changed-gulf-of-mexico-to-gulf-of-america/)

**Apple Maps Continues to Show Gulf of Mexico with Traditional Name Despite Trump's Executive Order**
Despite a recent executive order from US President Donald Trump to change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America, Apple Maps continues to show the Gulf of Mexico with its traditional name. The reason for this delay is not just political, but also due to the complexity of cartography. Maps are not just static images, but massive databases that are constantly updated. Changing a name on a map involves modifying a large amount of data, from geographic databases to user interfaces. Apple Maps is guided by international standards, established by organizations such as the United Nations Group of Experts on Geographical Names (UNGEGN), which aim to ensure consistency and accuracy in the representation of places on maps. Changing the name of a place with such historical significance, like the Gulf of Mexico, would require an international consensus, which is a long and complex process. 'The names of geographical places are subject to international standards,' said an Apple spokesperson. 'We take into account the importance of historical and cultural significance when updating our maps.' 
Original language: es
Publish date: January 22, 2025 12:00 PM
Source:[ipadizate.com](https://ipadizate.com/apple/apple-maps-sigue-llamandolo-golfo-de-mexico-en-vez-de-golfo-de-america-por-mucho-que-quiera-trump)

**Apple Resists Trump's 'Gulf of America' Decree in Apple Maps**
US President Donald Trump has signed a decree to rename parts of the US coastline and adjacent waters to 'Gulf of America'. However, Apple Maps still displays the area as 'Gulf of Mexico'. Republican Representative Dan Crenshaw tweeted at Apple CEO Tim Cook, 'Hey, Tim Cook. Just noticed that Apple Maps still calls it 'Gulf of Mexico'. Thought you should know.' Users quickly added to the 'Community Notes' with additional information, pointing out that the decree orders the Interior Ministry to take action within 30 days to rename the US coastline to 'Gulf of America'. The decree does not apply to the entire Gulf of Mexico, but only to the US continental shelf, bounded by the states of Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. Apple will not be forced to change its maps, as the decree only applies to public databases, not private companies like Apple. The company may choose to use a standardized international naming convention, which is set by the UN, rather than the US Interior Ministry.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 22, 2025 11:00 AM
Source:[macwelt.de](https://www.macwelt.de/article/2584672/apple-verweigert-sich-trump-dekret-in-apple-maps.html)

**Gulf of America? Not if You Use Apple, Google**
President Donald Trump's executive order to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America has not been adopted by major map providers, including Apple and Google. The order, signed on January 20, 2025, directed federal agencies to use the new name, but private sector maps have not yet made the change. Florida has become the first state government to follow Trump's policy, with Governor Ron DeSantis using the term 'Gulf of America' to highlight extreme weather conditions in the region. Tech companies like Apple and Google still display the body of water as the 'Gulf of Mexico,' with some social media users ridiculing the change. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and tech influencer Andrew Chen were among those who found the change amusing. Conservative journalist Jack Posobiec highlighted the lack of change on social media, posting 'Attention Google, this needs to be updated.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: January 21, 2025 05:40 PM
Source:[Newsweek](https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-gulf-america-2018291)

forecasters.initial_reasoning: The naming of geographic locations in digital maps is typically aligned with internationally recognized names and standards. Historically, companies like Apple have adhered to these standards to avoid political controversies and ensure accuracy. The Gulf of Mexico is the universally accepted name used in international and governmental records. There is no precedent for major companies arbitrarily changing widely recognized geographical names for reasons not supported by significant political or regional changes.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Compliance with International Naming Conventions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Apple Maps, like most major mapping services, follows international naming conventions such as those set by the United Nations Group of Experts on Geographical Names to maintain consistency and credibility. Deviation from these standards without a strong and legitimate reason is unlikely.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Potential for Political Influences
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Changes in geographical naming by major corporations can be influenced by political pressure or contractual obligations by governments. However, there is no public evidence of political pressure to change the name from the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technical and Procedural Constraints
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Implementing such a change on a global mapping platform involves complex procedures, including consultations with legal teams and compliance with international agreements, which would make any sudden change unlikely.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Geographic naming conventions on major mapping platforms like Apple Maps generally adhere to international standards such as those maintained by the UN Group of Experts on Geographical Names, requiring clear and consistent consensus for name changes. Furthermore, an Apple spokesperson emphasized Apple Maps' alignment with international naming inconsistency, bolstering the likelihood that such a major change would require significant international and cultural consensus, which seem lacking based on current events.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: President Trump's executive order to rename the Gulf of Mexico as the Gulf of America and the discussions around such adjustments on platforms like Google and Apple could imply pressure from certain political figures for quicker adaptation on maps. Reports of Apple partially showing 'Gulf of America' when specifically searched, even if not fully replacing 'Gulf of Mexico' on standard views, show some level of response.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, major corporations like Apple are cautious about making changes to widely recognized geographical names unless there is a widespread accepted change or a significant reason to do so. There have been no historical instances of major geographical areas being renamed on mainstream platforms without widespread international recognition and agreement. Furthermore, there are no recent precedents for tech companies independently renaming significant geographical features for any reason. Considering these elements, the base rate for Apple Maps displaying a non-standard name like 'Gulf of America' would be very low.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Standardization and Geopolitical Sensitivity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Apple, similar to other large tech companies, adheres to international standards for geographical names to avoid geopolitical conflicts and maintain neutrality. Any deviation from officially recognized names can result in backlash from users and affected regions. Given this, it is unlikely that Apple would display an unconventional name like 'Gulf of America'.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Risk Aversion of Corporations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Major corporations like Apple typically exhibit risk aversion towards making changes that could prompt public relations issues or controversy, especially regarding politically sensitive topics like geographical naming. This risk aversion reduces the likelihood of such a name change occurring.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Lack of Precipitating Events
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There have been no recent developments or announcements suggesting a movement towards renaming the Gulf of Mexico. The absence of any precipitating event that could justify a change in naming convention further supports the unlikelihood of Apple altering the name.

However, the implementation appears inconsistent and geographically limited.
